label: Letter from John Mathews to Nathanael Greene
description: Letter from John Mathews to Nathanael Greene regarding the possible battle strategies of the English as the end of the war draws near and how the Continental army should go about trapping the British troops.

metadata.label: Description

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[John Mathews to Nathanael Greene
November 30, 1781
[RvW Box 2 Folder 51; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

[Endorsed:]  From Mr. Mathews
Nov.r [November] 30th 1781.		
Philadelphia Nov.r 30th.1781
Dear Sir/		
[Endorsed continued:] Uti possidetis
Was assured that after
the Reduction of So.C.
Charles town wd be besieged
Mrs. G. accounting
I had the pleasure of receiving yours
of the 26th Ulto. by the last express.
We are under great anxiety here to
know whether any [and] what reinforcement
went with the British fleet from New York
to Chs.town. They have never kept any of
their transactions so profound a secret as
this. Should any considerable force be sent
to Chs.town; notwithstanding the reinfor-
-cement sent you, I dont see, that your si-
-tuation will be the least bettered. Unless
Virginia and North Carolina will make those
exertions they ought to. Much depends my
D.r Sir. on your situation by the month of
March. Should the Dutch continue firm [and]
act with vigour in the war – which all our
late accounts from that quarter give us the
strongest reason to believe they will – Britain
must at all events negotiate; how
far they may be seriously disposed for peace,
may be a question; how far they may be ad-
-mitted to play a fast [and] loose game, will in
a great measure depend on the situation
of their affairs in America. I have observed 
[End Page 1]
before, Britain has given up every Idea of
conquering the Northern states; her sole
dependance [sic] for concluding the war any ways
advantageously to herself is, in what she
can gain to the Southward. If she possesses
Chs.town with any considerable extent
of country around it, her claim to Uti pos-
-sidetis, will appear just [and] reasonable
on this ground, she can be preemptory
without being charged with obstinacy, [and]
turn the tables on her enemies, [and] charge
them with unjustifyable pretintions [sic], to
prolong the war. It is her business now, to
appear moderate, knowing our determination
never to relinquish any part of the Union.
This is the only true, substantial ground
on which she can have the least hopes of 
gaining friends, [and] it is not impossible it
may be a successful manuvre [sic]. By the last
[and] late, accounts from Europe, The Mediating
powers, were strenuously exerting themselves
to effect a peace. It is therefore probable that
from this disposition in them, they will not 
sit easy, under a disappointment in a mat-
-ter they seem to have so much at heart.
Reverse this state of affairs in America,
[and] see what will be the probable political
result. S[h]ould the British possessions be
[End Page 2]
confined to Chs.town, [and] their force in a manner
besieged there, the force of her claim quoad this
object, will appear weak, so much so, that
it would not be likely to meet the strenuous
support of the Mediations. Add to this, that
Britain herself must at once be sensible
that the benefit she could propose to herself
from such a possession, would by no means
be adequate to the expense of another cam-
-paign merely on that account. From –
these, promises I draw these conclusions.
That Britain, from the misfortunes atten-
-ding her affairs in all parts of the world, in
the course of the present year, from her ha-
-ving drawn on herself a new, [and] obstinate
enemy, without the least prospect of ac-
-quiring any friend, with resources, tho
by no means exhausted, yet much impaired,
in possession of no more than a couple of
towns, out of the thousands that she has
been contending for, I say under these
circumstances, Britain will be seriously
disposed for peace. But whilst she has
a superior army to the Southward, and
can penetrate the country ad libitum,
she never will make a peace with her own
consent. How far it will be in your power
to straighten their quarters I know not, but I
[End Page 3]
much fear your force will be inadequate to the
grand object. i.e. Confining them to Chs.town
You will no doubt say, this letter speaks
a different language from my former one,
true, [and] for a very substantial reason, I was
then taught to believe the reduction of Chs.
town, would immediately follow that, of the
enemie's [sic] force in Virginia; how well founded
my information was; you at present know 
as well as I do. The disappointment I must
confess, has been a most cruel one to me, both
as a citizen of So. Carolina, [and] as a citizen of
America at large; for you observe my opinion
is still the same; let us get possession of Ch.s
town, [and] the war is at an end.
Mrs. Greene has been some days in this
city, on her way to Carolina; being still close
confined to the house with the gout, I have not
had it in my power to wait on her, but all the
other Carolinians, both Ladies [and] Gentlemen,
have been to pay their respects to her. I fear
her going to Carolina at this time will disgust
her against the country, not only from its pre-
-sent confused state, but there will be scarcely
any of her own sex, with who she can asso-
-ciate. Adieu My D.r Sir, [and] believe me,
most sincerely yours
Jn.o [John] Mathews
[End Page 4]
